key_points: Derek Chauvin is seeking a new trial over George Floyd's death, following his conviction for unintentional second-degree murder, third-degree murder, and second-degree manslaughter.
Chauvin's attorney claims the trial had several errors, including jury and prosecutorial misconduct, and a verdict contrary to law.
The request argues that the jury was not adequately shielded from extensive publicity, impacting the trial's fairness.
Chauvin's filing mentions a controversy surrounding juror Brandon Mitchell, who attended a march wearing a shirt that referenced police brutality.
Mitchell, however, stated the march was attended to support voter turnout, not protests against police brutality.
The filing demands a hearing to investigate alleged jury misconduct and pressure during deliberations.
Law professor Rachel Moran believes it's unlikely the verdict will be overturned, highlighting the difficulty of challenging jury deliberations.
The original jury consisted of a diverse mix of six White, four Black, and two multiracial individuals.
Chauvin awaits sentencing with possible maximum sentences ranging from 10 to 40 years, depending on the charge.
Prosecutors have introduced 'aggravating factors' that could increase Chauvin's sentence, with the hearing scheduled for June 25.
spokespersons: Rachel Moran (University of St. Thomas law professor)
